div.head: Resources for Spoken Varieties
div.p: The number of digitally encoded Arabic language corpora has been on the rise in recent years. The following list is an attempt at listing some that are relevant to linguistic research and is by no means meant to be exhaustive. Please let us know about missing items.

div.head: CorpAfroAs
div.p: The Corpus for Afroasiatic Languages (CorpAfroAs) began as an integrated pilot project, producing transcribed and sound-indexed spoken data. The varieties included in the corpus were Moroccan Arabic, Tripolitanian Arabic (Libya) and Juba-Arabic (Sudan). The transcribed texts encompass both narratives and conversations, are text-sound aligned using Praat and ELAN software, and annotated for prosody and morphosyntax. The Arabic data comprises approximately 25,000 words. The project set an excellent example for then best practices. On their website, you can find extensive information on how to build corpora of spoken language. The data is freely available.

div.head: Multi-Arabic Dialect Applications and Resources corpus (MADAR)
div.p: MADAR consists of 2,000 parallel sentences translated into the dialects of 25 Arab cities. It was developed through a three-year international collaboration involving researchers from Gulf universities and Columbia University. The source sentences were originally from the Basic Traveling Expression Corpus (BTEC) in both French and English. The dataset is freely accessible and organized by city, with each version presented as tab-separated values in Arabic script without diacritics. Although it's highly beneficial for many natural language processing tasks, its usefulness for traditional dialectology is limited due to the absence of phonetic details and sufficient metadata. It is available through various websites, also through the Internet Archive.

div.head: CORVAM Speech corpus of Maghrebi varieties
div.p: CORVAM is a tool for the study of Arabic and Berber varieties in the Maghreb in terms of teaching and research and for the preservation of language and culture in the Maghreb. The corpus is a result of the research team nhəḍṛu. Dialectología y sociolingüística del Magreb, and has been conducted at the University of Zaragoza with the participation of members from other universities and research institutes both from Spain and abroad. The project was developed under the lead of Ángeles Vicente and the website is being hosted by the University of Zaragoza.

div.head: TUNICO
div.p: In contrast to the corpora mentioned above, TUNICO represents the language of a single location, the Tunisian capital. It comprises transcriptions of over 30 hours of dialogues and narrative interviews, collected in 2013 in Tunis. One of the project’s stated goals was to record speakers from diverse social backgrounds, all under the age of thirty-five, who have grown up and still reside in the Greater Tunis area. The project team attempted to realise a balanced gender ratio. The project, titled Lexical Dynamics in the Greater Tunis Area: a Corpus-Based Approach (TUNICO), ran from August 2013 until July 2016 and was the first of the VICAV projects. The data is partially annotated with lemmas and word-class information through several semi-automatic steps using the dictionary. Unlike other dialectological projects, TUNICO aimed to capture contemporary language and the speech of the younger generation, primarily high school or university students.

div.head: Tunisian Arabic Corpus (TAC)
div.p: This is a comparatively large corpus of Tunisian Arabic mainly collected from the Internet. The texts are supposed to represent spoken Arabic presented in Arabic script. According to the creators, TAC currently approximately 1 million words. The website (http://www.tunisiya.org/) was last updated with a new interface in January 2025.

The provided metadata gives author, a date and a rough categorisation of the texts, including folklore, poetry, popular song lyrics, collections of proverbs, and screenplays for movies, television shows and plays.

div.head: Corpus of Moroccan Arabic Writers of Short Stories and Literary Reviews
div.p: Information on this corpus in Arabic script can be found here.

div.head: In their own voices, in their own words: A sociolinguistically-informed corpus of Nigerian Arabic
div.p: This corpus created by Jonathan Owens who has published extensively about Nigerian Arabic represents dialects spoken on the periphery of the Arabic-speaking world. Over time, the texts have been available at various URLs in recent years (most recently at https://www.arabistik.uni-bayreuth.de/de/forschung/ehemalige-forschungsprojekte/index.html) and are made up of recorded and transcribed group conversations and interviews.

div.head: Curras: Corpus for Palestinian Arabic
div.p: This collection of 60k words consists in texts collected from Facebook, Twitter, "Watan Aa Water" scripts, and others. Every word in the corpus was manually annotated with a set of metadata attributes to describe the orthographical, morphological, and semantic features of the word such as part of speech, prefixes, stem, suffixes, dialect lemma, MSA lemma, surface, gender, number, mode, and a gloss in English. It is available as part of the SinaLab corpora, of Birzeit University.

div.head: Gulf Arabic Corpus (Gumar)
div.p: Gumar was created as part of the Computational Approaches to Modeling Languages CAMeL lab in New York University Abu Dhabi NYUAD. The corpus contains a unique genre of written material, anonymous publicly published long conversational novels. It contains texts from Bahrain, the Emarates, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar and Saudi-Arabia. It was also morphologically annotated, contains more than 112 million words in over 1,200 documents and can be searched online.

div.head: Dialects of Arabic
div.p: Yaron Matras’ Dialects of Arabic project was carried out at the University of Manchester between 2015-2020 and was created through interviews conducted with informants from Algeria, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Morocco, Oman, Palestine, Saudi Arabia, Sudan and Syria. Since the recent disappearance of the website the data has remained accessible as a spreadsheet via the Kratylos repository.

div.head: Arabic Dialects Dataset
div.p: This collection is one of several corpora being provided by Mahmoud El-Haj (Lancaster University). It consists in transcriptions of Arabic script of Gulf, Egypt, Levantine and Tunisian Arabic dialects in addition to MSA.

div.head: Arabic Speech Corpus
div.p: The Arabic Speech Corpus was developed by Nawar Halabi at the University of Southampton. It was recorded in south Levantine Arabic (Damascian accent) using a professional studio. Synthesized speech as an output using this corpus has produced a high quality, natural voice. It is released here under a non-commercial creative commons license.
